subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Lexical sets and QS letters
msgSnippet: Dear Anthony, I m having trouble seeing how to work a strictly phonetic approach in real life even within my own writing.  My family and I discussed recently
messageBody:
Dear Anthony,

I'm having trouble seeing how to work a strictly phonetic approach in real life even within my own writing. My family and I discussed recently the different pronunciations of the "t" in "train" that we have among us. The difference is that sometimes TOT is used, and sometimes CHURCH is used. Listening to myself carefully in this and similar words, I find that most of the time I use TOT, but on occasion I will start this word with CHURCH. Should I write the exact same word differently depending on which pronunciation I use in a particular context? Certainly not, since I intend the same phoneme in each context. Writing this word phonetically just introduces confusion.

Other consonant problems are one of emphasis. When I want to emphasize the word "Matter," I will use TOT in the middle of it. When I am not emphasizing the word, I use "DEAD" in the middle of it. Should I spell the same word differently depending on whether I am emphasizing it? I hardly think so. (Just as a note -- I use DEAD in the middle of "Matters" almost exclusively, even when emphasizing it.) In each case, the same phoneme is communicated, even if they are phonetically distinct.

There's been much discussion about vowels in this topic -- I think because vowels in English convey relatively less information than consonants do. However, adopting a phonetic approach causes countless painful issues in relation to consonants as well.

As an aside, has anyone else noticed that Read uses THITHER instead of THOTH in the words "with" and "without" on page 11 of QM? Is this really the way he pronounced these words? I can't even get my mouth to form that sound in the middle of "without." Of course, that might explain why he needed an abbreviation for "with" when WOW-IT-THOTH is so easy to write. I don't think this observation helps my argument at all, but it is an interesting point to consider as we discuss this. I guess I do use THITHER in the middle of "within," but never in "without." If I followed a strictly phonetic approach, I'd be spelling these two obviously related words with different consonants and increasing confusion. Instead, I think they should both be constructed using however I spell "with" -- in this case WOW-IT-THOTH -- combined with the appropriate suffixes.

Thanks,
Greg

Sent: Sunday, November 4, 2007 8:57:26 AM

Subject: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Lexical sets and QS letters



Here's my main objection in a nutshell:



- Kingsley spells "path" with #32 Ah and "as" with #30 At



- Most Americans spell both "path" and "as" with #30 At



If we must all now use #32 for the word "path" while still using

#30 for "as" it would be problem enough. But worse is that

most Americans could never use QS correctly as they would never know

where to put other words with the "apple" sound ( sampa /{/ ). One

could try to write a Byzantine rule to help but it would never work

because as John Cowan wrote earlier "...If you can't hear the

difference, you're going to make mistakes..." . And the result of these

inevitable errors will be more illegible than QS written in dialect

ever would.



Now if we let Americans use #30 for the word "path" then we must

let Tasmanians use #28 if they want. I have observed that this creates

no difficulties in practice and we will still all be able to read

their towering body of literature without difficulty.
